HANKEY,Secretary, Cabinet,2* Whitehall Gardens, S.W. 1.8th April, 1929. jT.g DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BicITANNIC. MAJESTY' S GOVERMMENTV.jC. R g T' Copy No.cabinet 12). (29) .CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the Cabinet held at 10,Downing Street, S.W.1., on WEDNESDAY, 10thApril, 1929, at 11.30 a.in.90mPRESENT;-The Right Hon. Stanley Baldwin, M.P.,Prime Minister. (In the Chair).Right Hon.jSir Austen Chamberlain, K.G.,IM.?., Secretary of State for"Foreign Affairs.he Most Hon.HThe Marquess of Salisbury,BK.G.,G.C.V,O. ,C.B.,HLord Privy Seal.HH Right Hon.Sir William Joynson-Hicks,Bt.,M.P., Secretary of State[for Home Affairs.lie Right Hon.Sir Laming Worthington-Evans,ipt. ,G.B.L. ,M.P. , Secretarympf State for War.jB Right Hon.fpir John Gilmour, Bt.,D.S.C,Jji. P., Secretary of State^g or Scotland.HRight Hon.Neville Chamberlain, M.P. ,Minister of Health.BRight Hon.Lord Eustace Percy, M.P.,President of the Board ofI Education.he Most Hon.Hpe Marquess of Londonderry,I K.G. .M.V.0., First, Commissioner of Works.The Right Hon.Lord Kailsham,Lord Chancellor.The Right Hon.W.S. Churchill, C.H.,M.P.,Chancellor of theExchequer.The Right Hon.L.S. Amery, M.P., Secretaryof State for Dominion affairs and Secretary of State forthe Colonies.The Right Hon.The Viscount Peel, G.B.S.,Secretary of State forIndia.The Right Hon.Sir Philip Cunliffe-Lister,K.B.E.,M.C.,M.P., Presidentof the Board of Trade.The Right Hon.W.E. Guinness, D.S.0.,M.P.,Minister of Agriculture andFisheries.The Right Hon.Sir Arthur Steel-Maitland,Bt.,M.P., Minister ofLabour.The Right Hon.Lord Cushendun, Chancellorof the Duchy of Lancaster.THE FOLLOWING WERE ALSO PRESENT;-Mr. P.J. Grigg, private secretary to the Chancellorof the -Exchequer. THE BUDGET FOR1929-30.(previous reference:Cabinet 12(29), Con-elusion 3.)At the outset of the Meeting the Prime Ministerreminded the Cabinet that the period between theBudget discussion and the Chancellor of theExchequer's statement in the House of commons would be much longer than had been the custom inrecent years, and he appealed to his colleagues in the interval to observe the most completereticence in regard to any decisions that might betaken.The Chancellor of the Exchequer then made astatement in regard to the results of the financialyear 1928-29 and a forecast for 1929-30, and laidcertain proposals before the Cabinet.After a preliminary discussion the subject was adjourned until 3 p.m. the same afternoon.2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1,April 10,' 1929.
